keyframes.Text: As the worldâ€™s appetite for food continues to increase, the need arises to grow food in places that have a lot of water already. This is the Amazon Rainforest in the Brazilian state of Rondonia.

This is the Brazilian State of Rondonia located in the middle of the Amazon Rainforest.  In the year 1984, the land starts off almost entirely dark green. All the dark green is rainforest, but if you look closely you can also see faint brown and tan lines cutting through the forest. These lines are the beginnings of roads.
If we move forward about ten years, the number of roads increases and lighter patches of green appear in the middle of the rainforest. These are areas where people are beginning to farm land.
By 2015, nearly the entire area has been turned into farmland. Most of this farming supports soybeans and grazing cattle for beef and soy that are being exported to the rest of the world.
